feature.name: daily wage calculator
feature.description: The daily wage calculator is a payroll system feature that automatically calculates and deducts daily pay rates for employees taking unpaid leave. It divides an employee's total salary (basic plus allowances) by the number of actual working days in the month to determine the appropriate per-day compensation amount. The calculator accounts for different leave policies (calendar days or working days) and automatically deducts public holidays from the working day count. Upon approval of an unpaid leave request, the system generates an automatic pay deduction reflected on the payroll table. This feature ensures accurate and consistent salary deductions for unpaid leave across the organization.

source_articles_index.title: How is daily pay calculated
source_articles_index.article_summary: Explains how daily pay is calculated for unpaid leave deductions. Daily pay equals total salary (basic plus allowance) divided by the number of actual working days in the month. The calculation accounts for different leave policies (calendar days or working days) and deducts public holidays from working days. Upon approval of an unpaid leave request, an automatic pay deduction is created and reflected on the payroll table.

source_articles_index.title: Introduction to daily wage calculator
source_articles_index.article_summary: Introduces the Daily Wage Calculator feature that provides flexible and customizable options for calculating daily wage rates. Describes three calculation bases (calendar days, working days, custom days), salary component selection options, and the three main areas impacted by the calculator (salary proration, leave encashment, unpaid leave deduction). Explains the distinction between calculation bases and notes regional labor law compliance considerations for UAE and KSA.

source_articles_index.title: Salary Proration
source_articles_index.article_summary: This article explains how Super admins can update salary proration settings through the Daily Wage Calculator (DWC) by navigating to Settings > Payroll > Daily wage calculation and selecting calculation bases (custom days, calendar days, or working days). Changes affect all active payroll transactions and require special handling when payroll months are open with existing prorated transactions.

procedures.procedure_name: Calculate Daily Pay for Unpaid Leave Deduction
procedures.when_to_use: When an unpaid leave request has been approved and a pay deduction needs to be calculated and applied to an employee's salary.
steps: Receive and approve unpaid leave request
Determine applicable leave policy (calendar days or working days)
Identify total days in the policy (e.g., 30 calendar days or 22 working days)
Identify public holidays falling in the month
Subtract public holidays from the policy days to get actual working days
Calculate daily pay using formula: Salary Amount (Basic + Allowance) / Actual working days
System automatically generates pay deduction and reflects it on payroll table

procedures.when_to_use: When setting up or modifying daily wage calculation methodology for payroll processing
steps: Access Daily Wage Calculator from Settings → Payroll → Daily Wage Calculation
Select calculation base: calendar days, working days, or custom days
Choose salary components to include in calculation (basic salary, basic salary plus allowances, or allowances only)
System applies selected configuration to salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deduction calculations

procedures.when_to_use: When Super admin needs to change how employee salaries are prorated based on days worked
steps: Navigate to Settings > Payroll > Daily wage calculation
Select the required calculation basis: custom days, calendar days, or working days
If payroll month is open and prorated salary transactions exist, reject the existing transactions before saving new proration settings

rules_limitations_constraints.rule: Daily pay formula is: Salary Amount (Basic + Allowance) / Number of actual working days in the month. ; The number of days used in calculation is either calendar days (if following calendar days leave policy, e.g., 30 days) or working days (if following working days leave policy, e.g., 22 working days). ; Public holidays falling in the month must be deducted from the working days to arrive at the actual working days used in the daily pay calculation. ; Pay deduction is automatically created and reflected on the payroll table only upon approval of the unpaid leave request.

Calendar days calculation uses actual number of days in a given month (e.g., 31 days in January, 28 days in February) ; Working days calculation excludes weekends and public holidays as configured in the company's public holiday calendar ; Custom days allow payroll managers flexibility to set calculation base according to company policies; most UAE and KSA companies use 30 custom days to comply with local labor law

Changes to salary proration settings affect all active (unpaid) amounts in the payroll table immediately upon saving. When payroll month is open and prorated salary transactions are submitted for one or multiple employees, the Super admin must reject the transactions with prorated salaries before saving new proration changes.

edge_cases_warnings.edge_case_or_warning: When public holidays fall within the month, they must be subtracted from the working days count before calculating daily pay. For example, if 2 days are public holidays and the leave policy is 22 working days, daily pay is calculated based on 20 days, not 22 days. ; Different leave policies (calendar days vs. working days) will produce different daily pay calculations for the same salary amount; ensure the correct policy is applied for each employee.

Calculation results vary depending on month length when using calendar days basis, which can impact final wage amounts for salary proration and leave encashment ; Different calculation bases (calendar days vs. working days vs. custom days) can produce significantly different daily wage rates and should be selected carefully to match company policy and regional labor law requirements

When payroll month is open and prorated salary transactions have been submitted for employees, Super admin must manually reject those transactions and then resave the salary proration changes to avoid conflicts.

The calculator accounts for different leave policies (calendar days or working days) and automatically deducts public holidays from the working day count.
